14.46.text:
Four years ago,
today exactly, actually,

17.13.text:
I started a fashion blog
called "Style Rookie."

22.67.text:
I started an online magazine
for teenage girls

28.21.text:
My name's Tavi Gevinson,
and...the title

33.08.text:
of my talk is,
"Still Figuring It Out."

35.33.text:
And the MS Paint quality
of my slides

37.71.text:
was a total creative
decision in keeping

39.79.text:
with today's theme,
and has nothing to do

41.67.text:
with my inability
to use PowerPoint.

46.17.text:
So I edit the site
for teenage girls.

49.42.text:
I'm a feminist,
I am kind of

51.38.text:
a pop culture nerd,
and I think a lot

53.08.text:
about what makes a strong
female character.

56.58.text:
Movies and TV shows;
these things have influenced

62.13.text:
So, I think the question
of what makes

64.17.text:
a strong female character
often goes misinterpreted,

67.92.text:
and instead we get these
two dimensional super women

70.96.text:
who maybe have one quality
that's played up a lot

74.38.text:
like, you know,
a Catwoman type,

76.63.text:
or she, like, plays her
sexuality up a lot,

81.75.text:
But they're not strong
characters who happen

84.04.text:
to be female,
they're completely flat,

89.38.text:
The problem with this
is that then people

91.50.text:
expect women to be that
easy to understand,

95.25.text:
and women are mad
at themselves

98.88.text:
When in actuality,
women are complicated.

106.54.text:
and women happen
to be people.

110.46.text:
So, the flaws
are the key.

112.88.text:
I'm not the first person
to say this.

114.63.text:
What makes a strong
female character

116.50.text:
is a character who
has weaknesses,

119.17.text:
who has flaws,
who is maybe not

126.13.text:
I don't like to acknowledge
a problem without also

128.04.text:
acknowledging those
who work to fix it.

130.29.text:
So, just wanted to acknowledge
shows like Mad Men,

133.17.text:
movies like Bridesmaids,
whose female characters,

141.08.text:
Lena Dunham who's on here,
her show on HBO

146.50.text:
she said she wanted
to start it

147.88.text:
because she felt that
every woman she knew

150.00.text:
was just a bundle
of contradictions.

152.25.text:
And that feels accurate
for all people,

154.13.text:
but you don't see women
represented like that as much.

160.50.text:
But I don't feel that--
I still feel that there

163.75.text:
is some types of women who are
not represented that way.

166.71.text:
And one group that we'll
focus on today are teens.

169.13.text:
Because I think teenagers
are especially contradictory,

172.71.text:
and still figuring it out,
and in the '90s

179.00.text:
and My So-Called Life,
and their characters,

184.92.text:
I mean the whole premise
of the shows

187.13.text:
were just them trying
to figure themselves out

191.75.text:
only lasted a season each,
and I haven't really

194.38.text:
seen anything like
that on TV since.

199.29.text:
So this is a scientific
diagram of my brain,

203.96.text:
around the time when
I started watching

208.83.text:
I was, like,
ending middle school,

210.46.text:
starting high school,
I'm a sophomore now.

213.96.text:
And I was trying to reconcile
all of these differences

217.38.text:
that you're told
you can't be

219.17.text:
when you're growing up
as a girl.

220.38.text:
You can't be
smart and pretty,

225.63.text:
You can't care about clothes
if it's not for the sake

229.42.text:
of what other people,
usually men,

233.38.text:
So, I was trying to
figure all of that out,

235.83.text:
and I felt
a little confused,

238.50.text:
and I said so
on my blog,

240.63.text:
and I've said that
I wanted to start

244.79.text:
a website for teenage girls
that was not this,

248.67.text:
kind of one dimensional
strong character,

253.38.text:
Because I think one thing
that can be very alienating

258.33.text:
is that girls then think
that to be a feminist,

261.13.text:
they have to live
up to, you know,

263.21.text:
being perfectly consistent
in your beliefs,

267.08.text:
never having doubt,
having all of the answers.

270.25.text:
And this is not true,
and actually reconciling

273.63.text:
all the contradictions
I was feeling became easier

283.50.text:
And this is a spread
from a zine

285.42.text:
that I made
last year when,

288.42.text:
I mean I think I've let
myself go a bit

290.08.text:
on the illustration
front since, but...yeah.

296.25.text:
So, I said on my blog
that I wanted to start

301.58.text:
and asked people to
submit their writing,

305.13.text:
to be a member
of our staff.

309.88.text:
My editorial director
and I went through them,

312.33.text:
and put together
a staff of people,

317.79.text:
And this is an excerpt from
my first editor's letter

321.42.text:
"Rookie, we don't have
all the answers.

323.63.text:
We're still figuring
it out, too."

325.29.text:
But the point is not to
give girls the answers,

329.08.text:
and not even give
them permission

334.25.text:
to understand that they
can give themselves

335.88.text:
that permission, they can
ask their own questions,

338.50.text:
find their own answers,
all of that.

340.29.text:
And Rookie, I think
we've been trying

342.13.text:
to make it a nice place
for all of that

347.63.text:
So, I'm not saying,
like, be like us,

350.13.text:
and we're perfect role models,
'cause we're not.

352.42.text:
But we just want to
help represent girls

357.25.text:
in a way that shows those
different dimensions.

360.13.text:
I mean, we have
articles called

365.75.text:
"How to Not Care What
People Think of You."

367.33.text:
But we also have articles,
like, oops...

375.54.text:
If you use that, you can
get away with anything.

380.58.text:
"How to Look Like You
Weren't Just Crying

384.00.text:
So, all of that being said,
I still really appreciate

387.13.text:
those characters,
you know, in movies,

389.54.text:
and, you know, articles
like that on our site

392.63.text:
that are just about
being totally powerful.

396.50.text:
Maybe finding your acceptance
with yourself,

404.67.text:
So, what I want you to
take away from my talk,

408.46.text:
the lesson of all this,
is to just be Stevie Nicks.

412.67.text:
Like, that's all
you have to do.

416.00.text:
Because my favorite
thing about her,

420.67.text:
is that she is very--
has always been,

429.83.text:
and about reconciling all of

434.46.text:
and she makes you

437.46.text:
And yeah so, please
